GameData.Language_en_US:
Koa
Powerful Medieval Era melee unit that starts with additional experience and specializes in amphibious combat. Does not require a source of [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron to be built. Only Hawaii may build it.
The Koa is the Hawaiian unique unit, replacing the Longswordsman. Significantly stronger but more expensive than the Longswordsman, the Koa starts with an additional 10 XP as well as the Amphibious promotion. Unlike the Longswordsman, the Koa does not require a source of [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron to be built and upgrades into the Rifleman.
Taking their name from the tree from which they crafted their diverse weaponry, the koa were feared above all other warriors in Hawaii. Their rigorous training, undertaken secretly in the night, honed their skills against enemy formations. Each sought mastery of Kapu Ku'ialua, often known simply as lua. Hawaii's indigenous martial art, lua focuses on joint locks, pressure points, and bone-shattering techniques, with an emphasis on strategy to compliment its role in oceanic warfare. Armed with this style, the koa fought with spears, staffs, slings, daggers, and hoe leiomano--an iconic shark-toothed weapon. In order to preserve the traditions of the koa, Kamehameha formed the pa ku'ialua--schools where young men continued to be trained in lua for decades after.
Matato'a
Classical Era ranged unit that starts with additional Sight. May search for a Manu-Tara Egg on a coastal Hill tile to upgrade into a Tangata-Manu. Only Rapa Nui may build it.
The Matato'a is a unique unit for Rapa Nui, replacing the Composite Bowman. Cheaper but weaker than the Composite Bowman, the Matato'a starts with additional Sight and has the ability to search a coastal Hill tile for a Manu-Tara Egg. If successful, the tile provides additional [ICON_PEACE] Faith and the Matato'a upgrades into a Tangata-Manu, which is stronger than both the Matato'a and the Composite Bowman and can embark and enter Ocean tiles.
The Matato'a were the chiefs and war leaders of the mata, the large kinship groups that divided the island among themselves. Beneath them served commoners recruited for battle, armed with clubs known as paoa, from which these lowly warriors took their name. The favored weapons of the matato'a, however, were the vero and the kakau, the spear and the javelin, both tipped with vicious mataa, an obsidian point said to have been developed during the war between the hanua 'e'epe and the hanua momoko. This legendary war may be connected to the 18th Century conflicts on the island, during which mataa became increasingly common and the matato'a assumed greater control over Rapa Nui. To further secure their rule and determine which matato'a took precedence over the others, they established the competitive mata veri ceremony to chose a Tangata Manu.
Tangata-Manu
Powerful Classical Era ranged unit that starts with additional Sight and can embark and enter Ocean tiles and receives a defense bonus while embarked. Only Rapa Nui may acquire it.
The Tangata-Manu is a unique unit for Rapa Nui, upgraded to from the Matato'a. Stronger than both the Matato'a and the Composite Bowman, the Tangata-Manu starts with additional Sight and can embark and enter Ocean tiles and receives a +100% Defense Bonus while embarked. The Tangata-Manu cannot be built or purchased, and can only be acquired through the discovery of a Manu-Tara egg by a Matato'a.
From the earliest days of Rapa Nui, the site of 'Orongo hosted the Tangata Tapu Manu rituals. Young men and women came to this holy site to undergo their initiation into adulthood. As the authority of the matato'a increased, they transformed these ancient rituals to legitimize their rule, creating the mata veri ceremony. When the mata veri, or Grand Assemblage, convened each September, the Rapanui enjoyed an island-wide armistice while the matato'a chose a new Tangata Manu. Either competing himself or through a proxy, the matato'a raced from 'Orongo to the tiny islet of Motu Nui. There, they claimed an egg from the manu tara, the sooty terns that nest on the islet. The first matato'a to return to 'Orongo with an intact egg was proclaimed the Tangata Manu, the Birdman. The new Tangata Manu enjoyed a year of luxury and privilege in special residence at Rano Raraku. His paoa could strike against his enemies with virtual impunity, and he oversaw the distribution of food on the island and served as the official intermediary between the people and Makemake, the avian fertility god that had usurped the ancestral Polynesian deities that had once been worshipped on the island. The emergence of the Tangata Manu brought about a renaissance of Rapanui art, both to commemorate the victories of the Tangata Manu and their new god, and among the more traditional elements of society still loyal to the 'ariki mau and intent on countering the influence of the matato'a.
Tongiaki
Fast Ancient Era naval melee unit that can enter Ocean tiles. Friendly embarked units that start the turn stacked with the Tongiaki can also enter Ocean tiles. Cannot capture cities. Only the Tonga may build it.
The Tongiaki is the Tongan unique unit, replacing the Trireme. Faster than the Trireme, the Tongiaki can enter Ocean tiles and allows friendly embarked units that start the turn stacked with it to do the same, even before discovering Astronomy. The Tongiaki cannot capture cities.
The Tongiaki was a resilient and robust double-hulled canoe. They were used by the Tongans to spread their influence and control over neighboring Pacific kingdoms. Relying heavily on the ocean winds, the Tongiaki was 70 ft. long and could reportedly carry up to a 100 people. However, the Tongiaki sacrificed its maneuverability for the weight it could ship, which would ultimately lead to their decline in use after a newer version that was more swift and agile would be adopted.

Heiau
Provides two random specialists when constructed. Requires no [ICON_GOLD] Gold maintenance.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Shrine.
In the traditional religion of the Hawaiian islands, Heiau served as the primary places of worship and of seeking the help of the divine. Heiau were established for a variety of reasons, with different types for individual purposes, including navigational success, treatment of the sick or fertility, among others. These heiau were not only for different purposes, but were entirely different forms, including semi-submerged heiau for aid in fishing, and varying from simple earth terraces to elaborate temple structures composed of volcanic rock with multiple pyramids. They varied in size, too, with the largest heiau being several acres in size (these ones were extremely sacred, and only the Ali'i nui and high priests were allowed to use them.) Following the decline of the traditional Hawaiian religion with the arrival of Christian missionaries in the early 19th century, many of the Heiau were destroyed or fell into disrepair, believed to be heathen.
The Heiau is the Hawaiian unique building, replacing the Temple. The Heiau provides two random specialists when constructed and increases the [ICON_PEACE] Faith output of this city. The Heiau has no maintenance cost. Can only be built if this city contains a Shrine.

Mala'e
Each source of [ICON_RES_CORAL] Coral, [ICON_RES_CRAB] Crab, [ICON_RES_FISH] Fish, [ICON_RES_PEARLS] Pearls and [ICON_RES_WHALE] Whales worked by this city provides +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food. Provides an additional +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food if this city is next to three or more Coast or Lake tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Allows establishing internal [ICON_FOOD] Food trade routes from this city.
The Tongan nobility maintained large fenced compounds in their capital. These compounds were multifaceted, but their largest features are the mala'e, expansive grassy areas containing a falu hau, or meeting house. Here the Tonga Tu'i hosted the 'inasi festivals, held meetings, and accepted tribute. Toward the rear of mala'e, the nobility built yet another fenced and gated compound for their personal residence, between 15-18 meters in length and over 6 meters tall. Surrounding the mala'e were the houses of the nobleman's wives and his retainers, storehouses, baths, ornamental trees and other luxuries befitting the noble's position.
The Mala'e is the Tongan unique building, replacing the Granary. The Mala'e increases the [ICON_FOOD] Food output of this city and provides additional [ICON_FOOD] Food if this city is next to three or more Coast or Lake tiles. The Mala'e allows you to establish internal [ICON_FOOD] Food trade routes from this city.
MC: Mala'e Food
Pa
The Pa provides +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +5% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when building land units. It can only be built on a Hill tile and cannot be built adjacent to another Pa. Friendly military land units stationed on a Pa receive a +50% Defense Bonus. Only the Maori may build it.
While almost any Maori village could be called a pa, today the word has come to refer to fortified hilltop villages almost exclusively. Ringed with palisades and terraces, these monumental structures announced the military power of a rangatira and his iwi to the world. Pa were built in strategic places throughout an iwi's territory, in order to best guard its fertile lands. A simple pa might consist only of a single palisade, while a more complex pa would consist of multiple rings of palisades, earthen ramparts, ditches from which to defenders can mount ambushes, kumara patches, food storage areas, wells, underground passages, and decorative entryways. During the Musket Wars, a new type of pa was developed - the gunfighter pa. These forts were usually simpler than the older varieties, but could be constructed in a matter of days. The gunfighter pa provided greater defense against attackers wielding firearms, as well as allowing defenders to the full advantage of their own muskets.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Pa provides +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food and +5% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when building land units. It can only be built on a Hill tile and cannot be built adjacent to another Pa. Friendly military land units stationed on a Pa receive a +50% Defense Bonus. Only the Maori may build it.

Greetings Te Rauparaha, noble Rangatira of the Maori people! May Tumatauenga and Tangaroa bestow their blessings upon you! You were the leader of the Ngati Toa, a proud Iwi famed for their valour upon the field of battle amongst friend and foe alike. When the European powers came to the islands of Aotearoa, you resisted their incursions into your lands while at the same time utilising their superior weaponry - the musket - to give you an advantage over your foes with whom your people had fought for centuries prior. It was with these conquests that your name came to be known far and wide, earning you a place among the greatest military minds of the age. Your achievements were not limited to the battlefield, however. It was your ability as a negotiator which successfully stemmed the tide of European settlement upon your lands through peace, not war. Yet not all of your people were as willing to support a peaceful solution, with many choosing to take up arms against the colonists. While maintaining a friendly relation with the colonists, you supported the opposition through the supply of intelligence, an act which would be your undoing. Yet even in prison you fostered your legacy, creating a powerful haka which came to embody the mana of the Maori on a global scale long after your death.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great Te Rauparaha, the Maori are once again under threat of invasion from imperial powers, and are in dire need of a strong, battle-hardened leader! Te Rauparaha, the gods and your people call to you to protect your lands against all foes. Can you reprise your role as general and chief? Can you fend off all those who would doubt your sovereignty? Can you build a civilization that can stand the test of time?
Malo 'etau lava 'Aho'eitu, the great king who came down from the sky. The Tongan people arrived on the island of Tongatapu some 3,000 years ago and quickly established themselves among the many islands of the surrounding archipelago. Astute sailors and fisherman, they ably adapted Fijian ship building techniques to assert maritime supremacy and conquer the neighboring Samoan Kingdom. A legend amongst your people, Divine Father, you established the Tu'i Tonga Empire which, at its height, stretched from the islands of Niue to Tikopia and created a sphere of influence that fostered transoceanic trade and cultural exchange. Yet this supremacy would not last, with infighting proving to be downfall of your dynasty as Samoa began to reassert itself across the South Pacific.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great King, though weakened from times past, Tonga has never lost its sovereignty to a foreign crown. Your kingdom has endured in a way that few could ever match. The memory of your once vast empire still travels across the waters which once sustained it, and on the wings of the seabirds which guided its navigators. Can you restore Tonga's rightful place amongst the great nations of the Pacific? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?
'Iorana Hotu Matu'a, father and Ariki Mau to the Rapa Nui people. Hailing from the Marquesas Islands, you followed a prophetic dream to find and settle a new home for your people at the navel of the world. The island that would come be to known as Easter Island proved an untapped paradise for the Rapa Nui, who quickly mastered its bounty developing advanced agricultural techniques and erecting the massive Moai statues which continue to captivate the world even to this day. Yet, it was your people's success that ultimately led to their downfall. Easter Island would prove too small as overpopulation and diminishing natural resources left the Rapa Nui divided and weakened to greet the arrival of European exploration. A mere fraction of their original size, the Rapa Nui were diminished further still as foreign-borne diseases and slave traders ravaged what was left of your once great civilization.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Supreme Chief, isolated from the rest of the world your people managed to craft wonders that far larger civilizations can only envy. Yet no longer are your people limited by the constraints of your island home. It is time to set sail and follow a new dream to a land of limitless wealth and potential. Can you lead your people into this new era? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?
